messages.content: You are tasked with creating a structured output from the provided user message.

Full request path:
- /v1/posts/{post}

All HTTP methods acceptable:
- false

Per-method acceptability for the path /v1/posts/{post} (based only on the code shown):
- HEAD: false
- POST: false
- OPTIONS: false
- TRACE: false
- GET: true
- PUT: true
- DELETE: true
- PATCH: true

Explanation:
- The routes in routes/api.php are grouped under Route::prefix('v1'), so every API route in that file is prefixed with "v1".
- The PostController is registered twice via Route::apiResource('posts', PostController::class):
  - Inside the auth middleware group it's limited to ['update', 'store', 'destroy'].
  - Outside that middleware group it's limited to ['index', 'show'].
  - Combined, the apiResource produces the standard resource routes for posts: index (GET /posts), store (POST /posts), show (GET /posts/{post}), update (PUT/PATCH /posts/{post}), destroy (DELETE /posts/{post}); with the "v1" prefix this becomes /v1/...
- The path /v1/posts/{post} corresponds to the show, update and destroy actions in PostController:
  - show(Post $post) -> GET /v1/posts/{post}
  - update(PostsRequest $request, Post $post) -> PUT and PATCH /v1/posts/{post} (apiResource defines both)
  - destroy(Post $post) -> DELETE /v1/posts/{post}
- The POST method on /v1/posts/{post} is not defined in the code (POST is defined for the collection path /v1/posts, not for the item path).
- HEAD, OPTIONS and TRACE are not explicitly defined in the route definitions â€” per your instruction to judge "based on the code, not on experiential assumptions," they are reported as not acceptable.
- "All methods" would only be true if a catch-all (e.g., Route::any or similar) were used; no such route exists here.
